Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: 4.1 Breach of Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment: Defendant's failure to maintain the security of the building's main entry door, leading to unauthorized access and theft, as well as allowing unauthorized individuals to occupy the premises, constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment implied in the lease agreement.

Stinson v. Summers, 235 Mass. 235 (1920).proposition: 4.1 Breach of Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment: Defendant's failure to maintain the security of the building's main entry door, leading to unauthorized access and theft, as well as allowing unauthorized individuals to occupy the premises, constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment implied in the lease agreement.
Stinson v. Summers, 235 Mass. 235 (1920).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns construction of an antenuptial trust, the exercise of a special power of appointment, jurisdiction, and the rule against perpetuities. It does not involve a landlord–tenant relationship, a lease, building security, unauthorized occupants, theft, or any discussion of a covenant of quiet enjoyment. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for a breach of covenant of quiet enjoyment based on failure to secure a building entrance or prevent unauthorized access.
Stinson v. Summers, 235 Mass. 235 (1920).relevant_excerpt: The fundamental question is whether the special power of appointment to the use of all and every child and children of the said Hannah P. Osgood "for such estates and interests, and in such shares and proportions, and to be vested in him her or them, at such respective ages or times, and in such manner, as the said Hannah P. . . . shall direct or appoint," which the donor reserved to herself as donee, is limited by the provision of the trust instrument...

Chapman v. Carman, 105 Mass. 434 (1870).proposition: 4.1 Breach of Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment: Defendant's failure to maintain the security of the building's main entry door, leading to unauthorized access and theft, as well as allowing unauthorized individuals to occupy the premises, constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment implied in the lease agreement.
Chapman v. Carman, 105 Mass. 434 (1870).support_reasoning: The opinion in Chapman v. Carman concerns the validity and construction of a charitable bequest and the treatment of certain residuary legacies. It does not involve landlord–tenant law, leases, possession of premises, or covenants of quiet enjoyment, nor does it address building security, unauthorized access, or related breaches. The cited case therefore cannot support the proposition about breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment in a lease context.
Chapman v. Carman, 105 Mass. 434 (1870).relevant_excerpt: “The gift to trustees, ‘to be by them applied for the promotion of agricultural or horticultural improvements, or other philosophical or philanthropic purposes at their discretion,’ can be sustained only as a charitable bequest. What constitutes a charity, in a legal sense, has been so fully considered in several recent cases as to leave no occasion for further discussion at this time… The only remaining question for our decision is, whether certain shares in the residue of the estate… are entitled to participate in the general income…”

Phipps v. Rand, 231 Mass. 346 (1920).proposition: 4.1 Breach of Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment: Defendant's failure to maintain the security of the building's main entry door, leading to unauthorized access and theft, as well as allowing unauthorized individuals to occupy the premises, constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment implied in the lease agreement.
Phipps v. Rand, 231 Mass. 346 (1920).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns mortgage law, specifically the effect of an extension agreement between a mortgagee and a grantee who has assumed the mortgage, and how that affects the mortgagor’s liability as a surety. It does not involve landlord‑tenant law, leases, possession, building security, entry doors, unauthorized occupants, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Therefore it does not provide any authority for the claimed proposition about breach of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment due to inadequate security or unauthorized occupants.
Phipps v. Rand, 231 Mass. 346 (1920).relevant_excerpt: "The extension agreement between the grantee and the mortgagee, without the knowledge and assent of the mortgagor, bars the present suit against the latter. It was held in Rice v. Sanders, 152 Mass. 108 that, when a grantee in a deed assumes and agrees to pay a mortgage on the property conveyed, he takes upon himself the burden of the debt or claim secured by the mortgage and as between himself and his grantor he becomes the principal-and the latter merely a surety for the payment of the debt."

Serino v. McDonough, 420 Mass. 199 (1995.proposition: 4.1 Breach of Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment: Defendant's failure to maintain the security of the building's main entry door, leading to unauthorized access and theft, as well as allowing unauthorized individuals to occupy the premises, constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment implied in the lease agreement.
Serino v. McDonough, 420 Mass. 199 (1995.case_name: Nashua Corp. v. First State Insurance
Serino v. McDonough, 420 Mass. 199 (1995.support_reasoning: The opinion is an insurance coverage dispute over pollution exclusion clauses in liability policies. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, covenants of quiet enjoyment, building security, or unauthorized occupants. Nothing in the reasoning or holding addresses breaches of the covenant of quiet enjoyment or premises security, so it cannot serve as authority for the stated proposition.
Serino v. McDonough, 420 Mass. 199 (1995.relevant_excerpt: We have stated that, when construing the language of an insurance policy, it is appropriate “to consider [whether] an objectively reasonable insured, reading the relevant policy language, would expect to be covered.” Hazen Paper Co. v. United States Fidelity & Guar. Co., 407 Mass. 689, 700 (1990). Furthermore, we realize that an insured is entitled to the most favorable interpretation of the policy language when there is more than one rational interpretation of the policy language, or where the policy language is ambiguous. Id. See Trustees of Tufts Univ. v. Commercial Union Ins. Co., 415 Mass. 844, 849 (1993).

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: 4.1 Breach of Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment: Defendant's failure to maintain the security of the building's main entry door, leading to unauthorized access and theft, as well as allowing unauthorized individuals to occupy the premises, constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment implied in the lease agreement.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The case does involve breach of the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, but the interference consists of the landlord’s failure to prevent repeated flooding and unsanitary conditions, not failure to secure an entry door, theft, or allowing unauthorized occupants. The opinion’s quiet enjoyment analysis focuses on sanitary code violations and flooding as serious interferences and on the statutory standard under G.L. c. 186, § 14; it does not address building security, unauthorized access, or squatting. Thus, it cannot be cited as authority for the specific proposition about security-door failures and unauthorized occupants constituting a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy… Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under G. L. c. 186, § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Bartula v. McClure, 439 Mass. 152 (1998).proposition: 4.1 Breach of Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment: Defendant's failure to maintain the security of the building's main entry door, leading to unauthorized access and theft, as well as allowing unauthorized individuals to occupy the premises, constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment implied in the lease agreement.
Bartula v. McClure, 439 Mass. 152 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion in Bartula v. McClure, 439 Mass. 152 (1998), as quoted here, is actually a Massachusetts reciprocal attorney discipline decision involving F. Lee Bailey and does not concern landlord-tenant law, leases, building security, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. It addresses attorney misconduct, misappropriation of client funds, and related professional discipline. Therefore it does not provide any authority for the proposition that a landlord’s failure to maintain building security or prevent unauthorized occupants breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Bartula v. McClure, 439 Mass. 152 (1998).relevant_excerpt: Disbarment or indefinite suspension is the presumptive sanction for intentional use of fiduciary funds with either the intent to deprive or with actual deprivation resulting. See Matter of Watt, 430 Mass. 232, 234-235 (1999); Matter of Schoepfer, 426 Mass. 183, 187 (1997); Matter of Elias, 418 Mass. 723, 725 (1994); Matter of the Discipline of an Attorney, 392 Mass. 827, 836 (1984).

Am. Training Resources, Inc. v. Brooker,.raw_text: Am. Training Resources, Inc. v. Brooker, 62 Mass. App. Ct. 475 (2004)
Am. Training Resources, Inc. v. Brooker,.proposition: 4.1 Breach of Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment: Defendant's failure to maintain the security of the building's main entry door, leading to unauthorized access and theft, as well as allowing unauthorized individuals to occupy the premises, constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment implied in the lease agreement.
Am. Training Resources, Inc. v. Brooker,.support_reasoning: The opinion is a wrongful death/negligent hiring case against a residential landlord, focusing on negligent entrustment of keys and foreseeability of criminal acts. It does not analyze, mention, or apply the covenant of quiet enjoyment (statutory or common-law) or any doctrine specific to breach of quiet enjoyment arising from building security or unauthorized occupants. While it discusses a landlord’s duty of reasonable care to protect tenants from foreseeable criminal acts, that is a tort duty, not the lease-based covenant of quiet enjoyment described in the proposition.
Am. Training Resources, Inc. v. Brooker,.relevant_excerpt: “Edwards’s fault of negligence in the sense of the Carson case is exacerbated by the fact that, as landlord of residential property in this neighborhood, he was under a duty — higher than that of a commercial landlord… — to protect tenants from reasonably foreseeable risks of harm, including foreseeable risks of criminal acts.”

Coveney v. McCloud, 10 Mass. App. Ct. 69.raw_text: Coveney v. McCloud, 10 Mass. App. Ct. 69 (1980)
Coveney v. McCloud, 10 Mass. App. Ct. 69.proposition: 4.1 Breach of Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment: Defendant's failure to maintain the security of the building's main entry door, leading to unauthorized access and theft, as well as allowing unauthorized individuals to occupy the premises, constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment implied in the lease agreement.
Coveney v. McCloud, 10 Mass. App. Ct. 69.case_name: Boston Edison Co. v. Brookline Realty & Investment Corp.
Coveney v. McCloud, 10 Mass. App. Ct. 69.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns utility billing disputes, primary jurisdiction, exhaustion of administrative remedies, and whether a civil action should be stayed rather than dismissed when an attachment is in place. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, lease covenants, building security, unauthorized occupants, or quiet enjoyment. Therefore, it provides no authority for the proposition that failure to maintain building security or prevent unauthorized occupancy breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Coveney v. McCloud, 10 Mass. App. Ct. 69.relevant_excerpt:
The judgment dismissing the action is reversed and an order is to enter staying proceedings in the instant case until the occurrence of a final administrative determination.

Where, however, barring a plaintiff from court might materially prejudice his rights, dismissal is not the appropriate remedy to accomplish the purpose of prior resort to administrative remedies. J. & J. Enterprises, Inc. v. Martignetti, 369 Mass. at 540-541. In such cases a stay of judicial proceedings may be the preferable remedy.

Regis College v. Town of Weston, 462 Mas.raw_text: Regis College v. Town of Weston, 462 Mass. 280 (2012)
Regis College v. Town of Weston, 462 Mas.proposition: 4.1 Breach of Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment: Defendant's failure to maintain the security of the building's main entry door, leading to unauthorized access and theft, as well as allowing unauthorized individuals to occupy the premises, constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment implied in the lease agreement.
Regis College v. Town of Weston, 462 Mas.case_name: Regis College v. Town of Weston
Regis College v. Town of Weston, 462 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the scope of the Dover Amendment and when a land use qualifies as being for educational purposes under zoning law. It does not involve landlord–tenant law, leases, or any discussion of a covenant of quiet enjoyment, building security, unauthorized access, or similar issues. Therefore it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Regis College v. Town of Weston, 462 Mas.relevant_excerpt: We first address the scope of the Dover Amendment’s protection of “the use of land or structures for . . . educational purposes.” Concluding that the statute protects only those uses serving primarily educational purposes, we then address whether the plaintiff has shown that the record before the motion judge contains evidence sufficient to create a material dispute of fact whether Regis East has as its dominant purpose a goal that “reasonably could be described as educationally significant.”
